document.title: Maryland Early Learning Standards Birth – 8 Years

DF18FBD4639F491289973DBCD5DB9796.description:
Understands
explanations when concrete objects
and actions support
the verbal
explanation, and
phenomena are
directly observable
(e.g., "When we
mix colors, we get a
new color. See
what color you get
when you mix
yellow with blue").

A18E421007B64EA0A9AC65216E2149C4.description:
Able to act out simple roles (i.e., “Look, I am a dog,
ruff, ruff”).

06D3893DC5714EBC80D44C85714B3E52.description: Identifies difference between fantasy and reality with adult support and prompting.

EC428FD14A9D4459923724A37EA3D868.description: Engages in Pretend Play and Acts Out Roles

761973DCE0F540B9A0CA3E39719CF611.description:
Begins drawing
in a more realistic
manner,
occasionally
oscillating between
realism and
scribbling.

A392EA1716AA46D2A1D61E4B9A47A2F1.description:
Develops generic
symbols for
repeated drawings
of common objects
like sun, dog and
house.

A0E761C87C4D4B179692D0397188E2DF.description:
Represents
People, Places, or
Things Through
Drawings,
Movement, and
Three Dimension
Objects

62C18F6DB6D1480EB489889EFE354540.description:
Begins to
reference past knowledge to create understanding of new information through pretend play (e.g., says “This game is like the one we played in Ms. Kim’s class).

71C22B8479A04344A27BC3CD3EAFFCB1.description:
Begins to
understand how to
use age-appropriate
classroom materials
with modeling and
prompting. Follows
adult direction and
modeling for an
assigned task (e.g.,
turning pages of
book with care,
then puts book
back onto shelf
with prompting).

8142B39489534E04B0C56950033A6F73.description:
Begins to
recognize where
materials belong.

EF090810136D4D81B6358CAA683A52AB.description:
Begins to help
with clean up after
activities with
prompting and
adult assistance.

E524142EC25C42F7A32F29D16577F31E.description:
Demonstrates
Appropriate Use of Materials or
Belongings and
Those of Others

9D98A39FD7394537BF09105CF77ED7D2.description: Engages with trusted adults during transition with support and encouragement.

36CFA07F951F47D0AEDD3A6350078E5C.description: Demonstrates comfort with the transition from home to the classroom environment (e.g., begins to calm down quicker and more frequently when parents leave).

F316E30A21D84A9B872FD03D2E68C568.description:
Demonstrates
the Ability to
Adopt to New Environments with Appropriate Behaviors with Adult Support

010EDB23B0EE4292B92968B9F6D973F1.description:
Demonstrates
the ability to stop
an engaging activity
to help clean up
with adult support.

5A7A1255BC634C289F428E4359177487.description:
Moves from a
preferred activity to
a less preferable
activity with adult
support and
assistance.

28EE1082FAFE4D83913DB5001557293C.description:
Responds to
visual or auditory
prompts and cues
to transition to the
next activity with
adult support.

D341F2D6BCF84426897D46FE0FDBBCD2.description:
Demonstrates
the Ability to
Postpone Activity
and Start Another

E896466D481B4D9299E637A6A2A17B63.description: Understanding & complying with classroom rules, routines, and expectations.

E52A2A433100435AA9F5F8152D1345FF.description:
Begins to
anticipate the next
activity in the
routine (e.g., asking
“Are we going
outside?” during
snack time).

997C8B8C88F247BAB10ED21545EFC3A1.description:
Behaves
appropriately
within the context
of the classroom
routines (e.g., sits
for brief periods
during circle or
washes hands for
lunch time.

5B31E396424C4C768B3549A83F51439F.description: Understanding & complying with classroom rules, routines, & expectations.

49C0DF79EF104EBC830B7B94BE49881B.description: Continues to learn simple alternatives to aggressive ways of dealing with conflicts (e.g., trades one doll for a desired one by saying, "You have THIS dolly, okay?").

4D6584E9E2C643099D445C8A5ECB7E15.description:
Seeks adults' help
in resolving a
conflict (e.g., goes
to dad and says,
"Jacob took my
truck!").

17584C4BC84B4E2E902F0CF6D80A27CF.description:
Accepts
compromise when
resolving conflicts
if it is suggested by
an adult (e.g., mom
says, "Jackson, you
can use that swing
as soon as Sheila
has finished").

3DEF7D073C974BBCB20DB18B93AFBF53.description:
Begins to have
real friendships,
even though he or
she may not
understand the
concept of
friendship or that
these relationships
may not last (e.g.,
says “my best
friends are Nathan,
Sharon, Enrique,
Cassidy…” and all
others in his or her
class).

9351E4495EA94F7E925198D5CEE513F2.description:
Attempts to give
aid may not take
into account the
other child's
characteristics or
needs (e.g., offers a
crying classmate his
or her own stuffed
animal, even
though the child
has another
comfort object).

3E7965E424EA47E1A888806E59FBCF89.description:
Offers basic help
to peers who are in
need, upset, hurt,
or angry (e.g., hug,
comfort object, pat,
encouraging word).

C226519E3DEB4FD3A5F7566B11E2EDC9.description:
Can adjust
approach to a task
to resolve
difficulties with
adult help (e.g., if
teacher suggests the
child rotate a
puzzle piece to find
a better fit).

96522167F1EE4BB4BC48D43D8D9ED421.description:
Continues to
stack cups or
complete a simple
puzzle
unsuccessfully
without an
emotional outburst
with adult support.

3F786ABA669C4D8BBCBE190625116952.description:
Insists upon
putting on coat
independently,
even though prior
attempts have been
unsuccessful.

9BE6AAAED7904E17B855A652943B90FD.description:
Persists in the
Face of Failure

2A2079BCF1454594AB12DC7155BB4A2A.description:
Notes sense of
accomplishment
when finishing a
planned activity
(e.g., successfully
drawing a figure).

919BD2B5B4CC4C3594057DC5B9E30F97.description:
Keeps working to complete a task even if it is moderately difficult (e.g., persists with a
somewhat
challenging wooden
puzzle).

0B735AA0C4B14B68AF0EA22FC81F68D8.description: Persists with a wider variety of tasks, activities, and experiences with adult prompting.

E05882EF752F48069A5F0184C62C45FC.description: Persists in an Activity From Start to Finish (Complete a Task)- -Independently

40FFF49B67A5402DA7AA32AD85D5454E.description:
Begins to
independently
select appropriate
materials during
specific activities
(e.g., when
presented with a
painting project
gets red and green
paint).

586100B843424EAEAC7098563A9DA94D.description:
Chooses where
to play during
center time.

FBB90CFF84AE43A9A4EFC6B89956473C.description:
Begins to actively
participate in
classroom activities
(i.e. answers
questions or joins
dramatic play).

FC7C6E41F155414B955022ECB775D024.description: Independence in Learning—Plans and Initiates Projects

3B1F25A4E4914C3B9FB55F4D98D5CAF9.description:
Starts to
demonstrate
enthusiasm for new
challenges and
experiences.

8151B3125AC9443298D6294DCBB2EEAC.description:
Continues to ask
numerous
questions, which
are becoming more
verbally complex
(e.g., asks, "How
do we get to Nana's
house?").

818CF36B318742579E382648A1B6B114.description:
Generates ideas
with teachers and
peers with adult
modeling and
support.

C192540088CE413C8E781A7BB73D4D73.description:
Seeks experiences with new toys and
materials (e.g.,
listens to stories,
plays with friends
at the water table,
takes trips to the
fire station).

5CC2A1D0442342B48016C185328E0B18.description: Begins to ask basic “wh” questions related to the environment (e.g., “Where is Sarah going?”).

6BF3F65E9D45465188B36774BE14078D.description: Desire to Learn—Ask Questions and Seeks New Information

FB1041D668EE4EA09B2AAE966351EB15.description:
When faced with
a problem can slow
down and think
through options
with support from
an adult (e.g., “It
looks like someone
is in your way.
What could you do
to get him to
move?”).

C86019987DE7483B95EC4E5212B53A41.description:
After a conflict
with another child,
can talk about
other ways the
problem might
have been resolved.

1C32EBE5EBD6452DB3696C5405AB5B92.description:
Continues to
become more
flexible in problemsolving and
thinking through
alternatives (e.g.,
when trying to put
on shoes, talks to
self about what to
do first. If the shoe
won't easily go on one foot, he or she
tries the other
foot).

CA7C6B0AFFEA4F5586044EAE19DFC496.description: Asks adults to solve or “fix” a problem.

0407FDDCB7F1460C9ABEAE6A8583F6F2.description:
Employs a
strategy to solve a
problem with adult
modeling,
prompting, and
support.

787EA654F86648918C7964F556F41EFA.description:
Flexible Problem
Solving - Seeks
Multiple Solutions
to a Question,
Task, or Problem

45BB00EF2A1E4B318DAA4DE7776EB867.description:
Able to sort
materials by two
different
characteristics (e.g.,
blocks go here,
dolls go here).

8A16DF06C8494DD8A440901A8994A7C5.description:
Can recognize
when making a
mistake and change approach with adult
help.

6D2A0AA7BE06474BA0E33303F79EE381.description:
Can learn to
follow different
rules in different
contexts and can
do so with
reminders (e.g., use
indoor voices
indoors but not
outdoors).

14780D6A0FBA477FA5276E03A09B0ED4.description:
Can enjoy games with rules and
follow the rules
some of the time.

9381FE6518834B3C9EFD886D48912043.description: Can take on a character in pretend play and sustain this role consistently for approximately 5-10 minutes with adult modeling and support.

376F584FC3BE4199993977E614494FB9.description: Can Flexibly Apply Rules to Games and Behavior

EC0E7803EBB042F88A74FF4FD9DF48A5.description:
Can enjoy
success at simple
memory games
tracking a few
objects or pictures.

DA3DB4414E874F4AB310D313F60AF5D6.description:
Can put down a
toy and remember
its location for a
brief period of
time.

F9FB3CEC7AC942B89892319A9211C162.description:
Can remember a
response to a
teacher’s question
long enough to
respond
appropriately after
waiting for a turn
during a short
group discussion.

8FBE0E9566FB4A2493BDD9B01B0D3400.description:
Can hold two
rules in mind long
enough to
complete the tasks
(e.g., “Throw your
trash away, and
then put your
lunchbox in your cubby).

455C599561AD43D58F4F66293036FE79.description:
Can consider
two options and
make a choice
when asked.

8EF6E99B9B484A2688DEEC3F5ED20283.description:
Can remember
and talk about what
has just happened
in a story and what
is happening now.

B123F685150C44CFB3571A35B9EEC6B1.description:
Demonstrate the
Ability to Hold and
Manipulate
Information

8E66E719EAF74303A2F96F7212507E9F.description:
Can return to an
earlier task after an
interruption, with
adult reminders.

8EA376FB62D7422BAE1BE05CEC7535D5.description:
Remains on task
during an activity
set by the teacher
for short periods of
time despite
distractions though
still may require
prompting from an
adult.

132EA26245C64D969E0EF70FD067E279.description:
Attentiveness—
Resists Distraction
to Maintain Focus
on Tasks Set By
Someone Else

954A7A3CAD974517BFB9EA0296180B85.description: Maintains focus on one activity for longer periods of time as long as the activity is age- appropriate and of interest (e.g., can repeatedly solve and dump out a wooden puzzle, even with other children playing in the background).

C46088F0A804423DBBD080CF4248B53B.description: Attentiveness— Resists Distraction to Maintain Focus on Tasks of Interest to the Child

DF529AC1844A4AE3A8B8C893F1AD56EF.description:
Shows progress
in resisting the
impulse to harm
self, others or
property in difficult
situations or
conflicts and using
language to express
strong feelings
instead (e.g., says,
"I really, REALLY
need that swing!").
May still fall apart
under stress.

69816CCCA8AC4707B5630C343E4DB63D.description:
Refrains from
Emotional
Outbursts and
Unsafe Behaviors

F7A35711AC4B44D8A2F0DAAAAB857FCE.description:
Able to takes
turns with
preferred toys with prompting from an
adult.

D3A6DB352A234463B2AF4903D2CDF6A1.description:
Can wait for a
highly desired food
or object with adult
reminders (e.g., can
wait to eat the
cupcake in reach
until the birthday
song is complete).

003484414B58441EBEAC4D82EE815E51.description:
Briefly able to wait for an object
without grabbing.
Can wait longer
with adult support.

BB461A6462484602AD334EA975690D27.description: Can enjoy games like Red Light, Green Light that require waiting for signal to do something with adult support.

0E1446B03AB0415782E8F5AECA5F115E.description:
May need to be
reminded to stop a
habitual action when it is not appropriate (e.g. continuing to go to the bathroom for paper towels even though they have been moved into the classroom).

34A334FEC8674D91BDA77F808D815390.description:
May remind
other children to
control their
impulses and
follow rules when
not able to do so
oneself.

FC5657F1507C4C918B22808D173B461C.description:
Developing the
ability to control
impulses during
structured activities
with adult support
(e.g., resist the
impulse to call out
before raising hand
during group time).

1643C1CD27F04A259BC9046394BDAC05.description:
Occasionally
avoids imitating the
negative behaviors
of peers with
prompting from an
adult.

ED863C9A65614DD88192218316FBDA42.description: Continues to learn simple alternatives to aggressive ways of dealing with conflicts (e.g., trades one object for a desired one).

A148082AAFD442BB9FBC4B666A9569DA.description: Seeks adults' help in resolving a conflict (e.g., goes to dad and says, "Jacob took my truck!").

295041CDC2834B84BB558C148BDC6883.description:
Accepts
compromise when
resolving conflicts
if suggested by an
adult (e.g., mom
says, "Jackson, you
can use that swing
as soon as Sheila
finishes her turn").

A48A8BD2A7674B728ECC09151F278FBA.description:
Begins to
recognize
differences or
similarities between
self as compared to
others (e.g.,
children with
disabilities, gender,
hair color, etc.).

1BB40A543F894299A3C741AF57054250.description:
Recognizes
Differences or
Similarities
Between Self as Compared to
Others

27ACFF8CD1C54A5585D716281E241A76.description:
Begins to
understand the
concept of sharing
with adult
modeling and
support.

D83D81C6A9DD4AB68E66479AD9644A47.description: Plays alongside other children (e.g., dramatic play, block table).

B9EEA022B7734C76BB814777F4E04A6B.description: Plays or Works with Others Cooperatively

94F61DBC9BE0457FBDCF623B0576C7FB.description:
Recognizes when
someone needs
help, but may not respond every time.

BC45AB3564294E06BB5D121A5852A02B.description:
Begins to express
emotions through
non-verbal cues
with adult
modeling and
support (e.g., body
language, facial
expressions, crosses
arms, and frowns).

FAA3C54502414A0EA8CD49F6F0923112.description:
Identifies basic
feelings (e.g., sad,
mad, happy).

2164F1A07A6A4EAE8CD535D23F13372C.description:
Expresses,
Understands, and
Responds to
Feelings/Emotions
of Others

0CDEEC083C844ACFB94221D05C4CC101.description:
Recognizes the
appropriate place
for items (e.g., their
assigned seat, rest
spot, etc.).

A710F45A23C44B749B8347666E259E66.description: Begins to independently select appropriate materials during specific activities (i.e. when presented with a painting project gets red and green paint).

70C33783D281431A8D9330F5413A29CD.description:
Chooses where
to play during
center time.

C6206E3115F3410591B36A0688FD6E74.description:
Begins to actively
participate in
classroom activities
(e.g., answers
questions or joins
dramatic play).

89D3EAD8C2A14C72812ADFBC51F94065.description:
Demonstrates
Independence inD
range of Routines
and Tasks
